instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.

threads.title: Question about <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MUX
threads.message:
I have a customer who sent in a board saying that it crashed while opening Chrome (which is eerily similarly to another thread here recently); he said it will crash or freeze when overloaded. Board passes ASD just fine, and I will be replacing <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR> as usual. My questions are:

1. Is the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MUX chip as common to develop cracked balls as it is on the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>? I've had ~10 2610 boards in the past that needed to have the MUX chip reflowed due to cutting off and/or video issues on boot. Is the 2850 MUX also susceptible to cracked balls? Considering if I should reflow this one for good measure, or just leave it be.

2. I see a lot of warnings about reflowing the MUX on the 2850 (corner gel/epoxy getting under the chip and necessitating a reball); is it more likely to fuck up due to the corner gel than the 2610 MUX? I've reflowed tons of the 2610 GMUX chips (I do it every time I replace <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>, just for good measure). Is there something about the MUX chip on the 2850 that makes it more difficult to properly reflow?

3. Is it possible for the MUX to be responsible for the freezing/shut-downs even if it passes ASD?

I don't take many 2850's, but I'm doing this as a favor for a good customer, and want to send him back a board that's as reliable as I can make it.

Thanks!

threads.title: Question about <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MUX
threads.message: MUX will not crash the system, don't touch it.

threads.title: Question about <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MUX
threads.message:
Excellent, thank you duke.

What will be the symptoms of a MUX failure/cracked balls on the 2850? No video at all? LCD going black during use, etc? The board will work, but then the LCD go black after the LCD freezes for a few seconds. So in other words, the cursor will freeze, then after about 5 seconds, the LCD goes black. Keyboard backlight still on.

Does this sound like the MUX, or the CPU/GPU failing?

threads.title: Question about <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MUX
threads.message: MUX will cause lines and distortion sometimes intermittent black screen, but system will not crash or reboot.
